items.content_html:
Description

There were some specific links to RFC 7230, these can be updated.

Motivation

There are new revisions of HTTP specs.

Additional details

There's not much straightforward to change here :( I had to leave 8 references to RFC 7230 in place because they require some deeper surgery to fix the surrounding content correctly. For example, #20744

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update some links from RFC 7230 to RFC 9110

items.content_html:
Description

There were some specific links to RFC 7231, these can be updated.

Motivation

There are new revisions of HTTP specs.

Additional details

A lot of these are straightforward substitutions. However, some are more gnarly so I've punted on those (see links below)

Related issues and pull requests

  • httpwg.org
  • Glossry page that needs more substantial rewrite to replace "payload" with the RFC 9110 term "content" - #20741
  • toUTCString() - this is JavaScript and the ECMAscript definition still refers to RFC 7231 explicitly https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/toUTCString
items.title: Update the simple RFC 7231 refs to use RFC 9110

items.content_html:
Description

Update content about Certificate Transparency to note that Chromium plans to deprecate and remove the Expect-CT HTTP header.

Motivation

Keep MDN updated and discourage developers from using obsolete headers.

Additional details

Chrome Platform Status

Related issues and pull requests

Matching BCD PR: mdn/browser-compat-data#17800
items.title: Update content about Certificate Transparency

items.content_html:
Description

There were some specific links to RFC 7540, these can be updated.

Motivation

There are new revisions of HTTP specs.

Additional details

At the same time, the notes mention a topic that applies equally to HTTP/3. So add that too. However, the specific comment about HTTP/2 compat is not expanded to cover HTTP/3, since there is not evidence that I am aware of.

See https://httpwg.org for more details.

Related issues and pull requests

N/A
items.title: Update links from RFC 7540 to RFC 9113

items.content_html:
Description

IDBVersionChangeEvent.newVersion can return null when the database is being deleted.

Motivation

I noticed one of my version change events had newVersion set to null and I was wondering under which conditions this could be the case.

Additional details

The spec mentions this value being null as well.

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Mention null in IDBVersionChangeEvent.newVersion

  • React is using jsx, let's mark them as jsx

Also fixed one side issue: You can't set body style in Angular component, so it's unnecessary css rule. (I also tested doing the whole tutorial if for some reason I would have been wrong) That change can be omitted from this PR but I feel silly for opening own PR for just that.

Motivation

Additional details

items.title: Framework syntax language: React as jsx, Angular as ts

items.content_html:
Description

Replaced the existing example in en-US/docs/web/css/animation with five new examples. The five examples are

  1. Naive Sun Rise
  2. Efficient Sun Rise
  3. Animating Multiple Properties
  4. Applying Multiple Animations
  5. Cascading Multiple Animations

'Naive Sun Rise' is intended as a replacement for the original 'Cyclon Eye' example. 'Cyclone Eye' animates a box model property to create a borg-like loading bar. 'Naive Sun Rise' does the same thing but matches the theme new examples. 'Naive Sun Rise' also contains comments that discourage animating box model properties.

'Efficient Sun Rise' does the same thing as 'Naive Sun Rise' by animating a transform property. There really isn't an explanation, or link to something, explaining what makes the transform property more efficient—other than a comment about using the GPU.

'Animating Multiple Properties' makes the sun rise and changes the suns color. Two additional properties are changed. One of the new properties is allowed to 'default' instead of being set explicitly in both sides of the 'from/to' clause for demonstration purposes.

'Applying Multiple Animations' is a direct response to issue #19852. The color and rise aspects are separated into two different animations. The animations use differing animation properties for demonstration purposes.

'Cascading Multiple Animations' hints at a common mistake made by people new to animations—at least, I made it a lot. It is tempting to create two animations that utilize the transform property (expecting that they will combine). Combination does not happen, instead only the properties from the animation lowest in the cascade will be honored.

Motivation

To resolve issue #19852 and give actionable animation examples.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #19852
items.title: Improve animation examples

items.content_html:
Description

Clarify that using overscroll-property on iframe elements does not have an effect.

Motivation

It might seem that overscroll-property can solve scroll-chaining for iframes, but iframes with scroll bars are not scroll container elements, so this property does not apply. This was surprising and I wasted a lot of time to find out why.

Additional details

firefox issue and chrome issue.

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Clarify overscroll-behaviour for iframe elements

items.content_html:
Description

Add more terminology, and explain it better (TODO) like the old spec drafts used to explain.

The DOM spec is really bad at explaining in comparison.

Aside:

Why were those excellent explainers and diagrams not included in the final DOM spec to help people understand better so they can take advantage of the concepts?

Why were terms like "composed tree" and "flat tree" removed from the specs? Without those terms, it is difficult to explain concepts to people, or to have a point of reference when talking to someone.

The DOM spec currently explains via API requirements and algorithms, but not explainers and diagrams, which is unhelpful.

Motivation

To teach people by bringing those explainers from the old spec drafts to MDN (WIP, starting here).

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: WIP update "Using Shadow DOM" guide

items.content_html:
Description

Changed use of resource hash example from "deadbeef" to "cafebabe".

Motivation

My imagination is a bit too graphic and can imagine there are more people like me out there who might get triggered. Changed the sample to something a bit more positive ^_^

Additional details

Reference of other hexspeak phrases - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexspeak
items.title: docs: changed "deadbeef" to "cafebabe"

Description

The code example for a shared worker has 2 event handlers: onconnect and port.onmessage. The paragraph below wrote about a message handler, but I believe the author meant onmessage handler.

Motivation

Making sure to not confuse additional readers about a named function that isn't in the example.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update the name of the message handler for ww

items.content_html:
Description

Closes #18880

The important part is realizing that the performance degradation only happens after property accesses have already happened, which is not the case during constructor definition. The point about ergonomics still stands, but I decided to (1) properly illustrate how Object.create() should work and (2) explicitly point out the performance trade-offs.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Properly illustrate re-adding constructor property
